collection.institution: Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi — Muğlalı Hoca Mustafa Efendi Koleksiyonu

manuscript.title: Dîvân-ı Sâʾib-i Tebrîzî
manuscript.author: Sâʾib-i Tebrîzî, Mîrzâ Muḥammad ʿAlī b. Mîrzâ ʿAbdurraḥîm et-Tebrîzî el-Isfahânî (d. 1087/1676)
manuscript.notes: Undated. Multicolumnar layout (musirlidir). Persian dîvân in taʿlîk script. Cataloguer: Nimet İpek. Opening bifolio (ff. 1b–2a) carries the full decorative programme: derkenar halkârî paintings, polychrome serlevha (illuminated headpiece), and tezhip on f. 49a. Sa'ib Tabrizi is the foremost Persian poet of the sabk-i hindî ('Indian style') and one of the most widely copied Persian poets in Ottoman manuscript culture of the 17th–18th centuries.

paper_decoration.summary: The opening bifolio (ff. 1b–2a) is decorated with dense polychrome halkâr (halkârî) margin paintings depicting naturalistic Ottoman shükûfe flowers — tulips (lâle), roses (gül), narcissi, and carnations (karanfil) — executed in pink, red, green, and gold on both pages. The right page carries an illuminated serlevha with a blue-and-gold medallion and rectangular panels. A multi-colour cedvel framing system in gold, red, and green defines the text block. A further illuminated headpiece occurs at f. 49a. The polychrome halkâr palette — combining pink, red, green, and gold — is distinctive and consistent with later Ottoman (17th–18th century) luxury manuscript production.

technique_terms.ottoman: derkenar halkârî bezemeli; çok renkli halkâr; şükûfe; cedvel

catalogue_description.notes_field: Musirlidir. Cedveli lacivert, kırmızı, yeşil ve altın rengi mürekkeplerle çizilmiştir. 1b-2a sayfaları derkenar halkârileriyle bezelidir.

key_indicators: Polychrome halkâr with naturalistic Ottoman shükûfe flowers (tulips, roses, narcissi, carnations) — canonical Ottoman court floral vocabulary
Multi-colour cedvel in gold, red, and green: characteristic Ottoman luxury framing system
Illuminated serlevha with blue-and-gold medallion consistent with Ottoman tezhip conventions
Taʿlîk script used for Persian poetry: standard for Ottoman copies of Persian dîvâns from the 17th century onward
Sa'ib Tabrizi (d. 1087/1676) was widely copied in Ottoman Istanbul; peak copying activity c. 1680–1780
cross_tradition_caveats: Manuscript is undated; precise placement within the 17th–18th century range requires codicological examination
Sa'ib's dîvân was also copied in Safavid Iran and Mughal India; Safavid or provincial Iranian production cannot be excluded without physical examination of paper stock and pigment analysis

Polychrome halkâr is attested in both Ottoman and Safavid luxury manuscripts; the Ottoman attribution rests primarily on the tulip-dominant shükûfe vocabulary and the specific blue-and-gold serlevha format

paper.description: Not described in catalogue; paper type unrecorded
paper.color: Apparently plain (uncolored) text pages; halkâr painted in margins

ruling.description: Multi-color cedvel: gold, red (kırmızı), green (yeşil), and blue (lacivert) ink ruling

binding.description: Şemseli ve mikleplı siyah deri cilt — black leather binding with şemse medallion and envelope flap (mıklep)

codicology.condition_summary: No condition issues noted in catalogue record. Opening bifolio decoration appears intact at IIIF resolution.

limitations: Only the opening bifolio (p003 IIIF viewer page) was examined; decoration of f. 49a (third tezhip headpiece) not captured
Particle-level detail of gold halkâr technique not fully resolvable at IIIF viewer resolution
Folio count (approx. 348) and full extent of decoration programme unverified beyond opening bifolio

decoration_observed: Dense polychrome halkâr margin painting filling all four margins of both pages: naturalistic Ottoman shükûfe flowers including tulips (lâle), roses (gül), narcissi, and carnations (karanfil) in pink, red, green, and gold
Illuminated serlevha (ʿunwān) on right page (f. 1b): blue (lacivert) and gold medallion with rectangular panel flanking elements
Multi-colour cedvel framing system: gold, red (kırmızı), and green (yeşil) ruling lines enclosing the text columns
Text in taʿlîk script, confirming Persian poetry manuscript
folio_analyses.notes: High-quality Ottoman halkâr with polychrome palette. The combination of pink, red, green, and gold in the shükûfe vocabulary is consistent with later Ottoman (17th–18th c.) luxury production. The blue-and-gold serlevha and multi-colour cedvel complete a fully articulated luxury opening.

terms_used.english: Shaded gold floral painting in margins; subtypes include taramalı (hatched) and tahrirli (outlined)
Marginal note or marginal zone; here used in the specific phrase 'derkenar halkârî' = margin halkâr painting
Illuminated headpiece at the opening of a text
Frame lines ruling the text block; multicolor in this manuscript (gold, red, green, blue)
Collected poetic works of a single poet, arranged by rhyme scheme
Blossoms; naturalistic Ottoman floral ornament: tulips (lâle), carnations (karanfil), roses (gül), narcissi
Hanging cursive script; standard for Persian poetry in Ottoman manuscript culture from the 17th c. onward

suggested_collections.reason: Largest holding of luxury Ottoman dîvân manuscripts with polychrome halkâr openings; parallels for Sa'ib Tabrizi copies with Ottoman tezhip.
Significant collection of Persian dîvân manuscripts in taʿlîk with Ottoman and Safavid halkâr margins; comparative material for the shükûfe vocabulary.
Persian dîvân manuscripts including Sa'ib copies with Ottoman-style decoration; Elaine Wright's cataloguing provides detailed technical descriptions.

analysis_metadata.image_quality_notes: IIIF viewer resolution sufficient for macro-level decoration identification and halkâr classification. Gold particle detail and fine brushwork within the halkâr not resolvable. Serlevha colour values readable.
analysis_metadata.folios_not_examined: f. 49a (third tezhip headpiece noted in catalogue) not captured in visual confirmation session. Approximately 344 text folios unexamined.
